title: ECB Chief Executive unable to answer how much has been spent on the Hundred to date in front of Parliamentary select committee
text:
Tom Harrison, the chief executive of the England & Wales Cricket Board, repeatedly failed to answer how much had been spent on the Hundred so far as the ECB were grilled at a Department of Culture, Media and Sport select committee in Parliament.

“Mr Harrison, it’s a simple question. What is the budget and how much have you spent?” Jo Stevens, MP for Cardiff South, asked. Harrison was unable to answer with a figure but said that it was in line with the ECB’s prior expectations of costs for the Hundred.

In evidence given later to the DCMS select committee, Andy Nash, formerly the chairman of Somerset and an independent director of the ECB, said that the Hundred would cost £60 million a year, once payments to the counties during the competition were taken into account. The ECB expects annual income from the tournament to be around £51m a year, which would equate to a loss of around £7m from the total £58m costs, including county payments.

Nash attacked the Hundred as an “almighty punt” and “reckless gamble”, and said that the tournament posed an “existential risk to the game”. A better alternative, Nash said, would be to make the T20 Blast a two-divisional competition, with promotion and relegation, which would be “much lower risk”.
